When you talk to end users, what they want to see in anomaly detection system, they will of course expect you'll be able to analyze huge amounts of data and do really complex analysis, not just some simple statistics.
And of course they want to know if something is wrong really fast.
And when you report something, it has to be actionable.
And by this we mean.
The operator, or somebody who's in charge of some system when he gets a report that something is wrong.
He needs to understand it and he needs to be able to do something about it.

So if you just tell him like oh, the sigmoid function returns to higher value, it's like OK, but if you tell him this part of the system is misbehaving and it's projected to fail within 5 minutes, then he's like, Oh yeah, let's go and do something about it and this.
Is very important points 'cause it's you go out of the scope of mathematics and statistics and you go into the area where user gives you his perceived value of your report.
So something that is statistically super significant can be worthless to your user and the other way around.
So user feedback is really important.

Is it critical?

It's a complex system.

Which area is the root cause?

Critical state, but is there any indication that something will go wrong in the near future so we can already prepare an?

Our practical experience comes from several areas.
One is the infrastructure.
We did it monitoring in Bloomberg where they have different several servers, several services running on those servers.
They monitor network communications among those servers.
They monitor database and other storage engines for the interaction.
Layton season volumes and so on.
And we had to figure out with all these data coming in with different latency whether something is wrong and try to correlate stuff.
Security is mentioned here.

We didn't touch into that, but just to tell you that security is a special area for anomaly detection, because every security alert is really important to them and there are specific algorithms to addressing these.
We didn't do that, but just to let you know that it's there.
The other area that we're focusing on is manufacturing, so we have industrial plant.
You can do a normal detection in several areas, like on the shop floor.
So where you have production lines you can.
Do all sorts of sensors and monitor if stuff is going on as planned.
You can use logistics, so are the input materials coming in that we have enough stock?
Is it being consumed as it should be?
Are consuming more or less?
Are we producing enough?
Are we shipping stuff the way we want?
The way we plan and this is so when you do planning of work for particular industrial plans, you need to take this stuff into account.
